ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a great deal not only about women in the workforce but also about public policy in general.

Women, Firms, and the State offered us the opportunity to explore the ways in which various systems of government, laws, and private businesses influence gender equity in the work force. Beyond providing us in depth knowledge about domestic and global efforts to empower women to be both represented and treated equally in the labor force, the course challenged us to consider what entities are best equipped to tackle issues like unethical workplace policies, stereotyping, wage gaps, and other impacts.
I strengthened my critical thinking and writing with the 8 reading responses that were required.

The weekly reading critiques allowed me to engage with the texts in a more meaningful way than I have in other classes. Additionally, the ability to connect different course themes under one title made writing the final research paper extremely easy to work through.
Learned about structural and sociocultural barriers that prevent women's labor force participation/professional advancement.
I learned about the inner workings of policy, companies, and how they impact women specifically. I learned how to efficiently read studies which was a much needed skill.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed the level of engagement in class.
Professor Latura is very knowledgeable in her field and while I sometimes felt that discussions were silent, I believe this was because of our very very small class size.

Strengths: super engaging course! The readings were all very interesting and not too overwhelming each week, Professor Latura was wonderful in facilitating conversation during seminar, and the assignments/grade distribution was pretty low-stress.
Weaknesses: none

I liked how small the seminar was. I never felt the pressure to participate because I j we I would have the chance and could also do so without the fear of taking up too much air time. Professor Latura was very clear in her syllabus about how the class worked so there were no issue of me following along. The biggest weakness of the course was that the material was very two dimensional and not intersectional at all. Professor Latura did disclaim that at the beginning of the semester but Im really failing to see how she can talk about the issues women face and not also talk about race and class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Participating in this class was an enjoyable way to start my week.

I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in exploring gender equity from a political, social, and economic lens. Professor Latura created an engaging environment for us to learn both from her and one another. Class wasn't just informative, it was an enjoyable and interactive experience where we were encouraged to share our perspectives and ideas.
Definitely! This class was very eye opening and helped me understand the gender equality issues faced my women through a new perspective

Yes, I loved discussing different policies and evaluating them as a group. The sessions were always pleasant and Professor Latura encouraged us to think critically about policy, something I particularly loved.
Absolutely. One of the best classes I've taken at Yale.
I would recommend this course to any student vaguely interested in policy and companies. It was really enlightening to see how exactly companies exist as they do today.

extras.title: PLSC 388 01 - Women, Firms, and the State
